question: I want to congratulate Kevin and Tracy on their engagement. I knew you guys were meant for each other from the moment Tracy told us she was pregnant. What? What did I say? What?
answer: Look at this -- people are getting married, they're getting married...

question: You said that.
answer: We're falling behind. You know who we are?

question: Tell me.
answer: We're the guys who clean up after the parade.

question: I'm gonna stick this right in your eye.
answer: I was at this comedy club last week and this comedian says "If you're over thirty and your job requires you to wear a name tag, you screwed up your life." And I'm laughing and then I realize I wear a nametag.

question: So do I. So what? I'm doing all right.
answer: Your brother's here.

question: What's up?
answer: Where were you?

question: I was... having dinner with Shari and her parents. I'm telling you, it's closing in on me. All of a sudden it's like a thing, it's a whole thing.
answer: What do you mean all of a sudden? You've been going with her six months.

question: I know. I mean I'm sitting there and her father's asking me about my "career prospects" and I'm playing "Risk," with her kid brother, Leon and at dinner the dog's sniffing at my balls -- at least I hope it was the dog. 'Cause her mother disappeared for a while.
answer: You know, those are for everybody.

question: Yeah, what - they put some schmuck on TV all day long or something?
answer: You know, that would be like a great thing.

question: What?
answer: That! Being that guy. Being the guy they watch.

question: What are you drunk?
answer: Yeah, but let's stay on one subject. Whoever that person is is going to be famous. They'll be able to get whatever they want. They'll ... trust me, this is my business.

question: What is?!
answer: Show business.

question: You're in show business?
answer: Yeah. I service video equipment.

question: That's like... those people stitching Nikes in Panama saying they're in the NBA.
answer: I'm not stitching Nikes in Panama! ... Bedwetter!

question: Thumbsucker!
answer: I'm making a tape.

question: We're excited. So Ray met the family.
answer: Yeah...

question: I hear the dog really liked him.
answer: Oh, the whole family loved him. Of course, they loved the last guy I went out with, and he strung me along for three years and dumped me.

question: Really? You see, to me, you shouldn't have any trouble with men. There should be, like, a line behind you.
answer: You shouldn't drink.

question: Jesus!
answer: And, you know, every guy I ever broke up with, the minute it was over, I could tell you what went wrong, how it went wrong, why it had to go wrong... but when I'm in it... lost. I'm like a love coroner. Bring me the corpse, I'11 tell you what killed it. But how to prevent it? Lost.

question: Hello I'm Ed. What smells? What is that smell? Oop, I think it's this idea. One person on TV all day long? Are you nuts? Seriously, get your resumes in order. When my brother Ray - whose personality you were just dazzled by -- told me he was going to try out for this -- I said, "why in the world would anyone want to be on TV all day long, no privacy, everybody knowing your business, exposing every single detail of your life I mean... why would anyone want to do that? But then I thought of a reason... Why the hell not? We'11 take care of it. Here. This time throw it out, don't eat it. Lou, can I talk to you a second?
answer: Um, yeah, I was gonna ...

question: What's the deal? Did anybody make a decision -
answer: Ed, look, uh... you're not getting the job. They're gonna transfer someone from another store to manage this store when I leave to manage the new store. I'm sorry.

question: Oh, Christ. Did you go to bat for me?
answer: I batted!

question: You batted or you bunted?
answer: Hey. I went as far as I felt comfortable. I mean, you know, let's face it -- you come and go here as you please. You work when you feel like it -- you know, Bruce Springsteen's birthday is not a legal holiday.

question: Well, then I'm quitting.
answer: Ed, come on. What's that gonna do? You're gonna bring Blockbuster to their knees. Let me recommend a movie to you. It's called "Get your shit together before it's too late."

question: He's who we want to go with.
answer: This guy.

question: I polled my staff. The men say they'd hang around with him and the women say he's fuckable. And one of the men said he's fuckable.
answer: I'm not sure about the entire concept.

question: Look it's not like we're burning up the airwaves now. We're running neck-and-neck with The Gardening Channel. If people just tune in to this twice a day for five minutes, we're a hit. Plus we can sell advertising every second, running at the bottom of the screen... and the beauty is this guy doesn't even have to be good. I mean if he's good, great. But if he winds up making an ass of himself, better. Come on. People cannot turn away from an accident. You drive by, you say "Ooh, I hope there's not a head lying in the road" but you look ! See, nobody in America wants to be nobody. This guy wants to be famous. So, basically, the deal is he agrees to drive down the highway a hundred miles an hour blindfolded and we get to see if his head winds up rolling down the highway. Fun for the whole family. So let's do it.
answer: Good luck.

question: Hey...
answer: Oh!

question: I got your message. Way to go!
answer: Hi, Shari. Let's go in the stockroom.

question: So when do you start?
answer: I ... I'm not gonna do it.

question: What?
answer: Look -- there's a million ways to humiliate yourself - I gotta think of a new way? I mean, it's all day! Every minute. Id be like a monkey at the zoo. I just...

question: In a second! In a hot second. Let me ask you something --

question: All right. Let me ask you something... are you happy like this?

question: Oh Yeah? What's your master plan here? You're gonna be a video store clerk for the rest of your life? This is your big ambition, rearranging the "Ernest" movies?

question: How many opportunities are you going to get in your life?

question: That's right. You don't know. Doors don't fly open for guys like us.

answer: All right.

question: Yeah?!
answer: Yeah.

question: What happens when you go to the bathroom? Do they go in with you?
answer: No. The bathroom is off limits -and when I go to sleep they go to other programming. Unless I get up. Then they go back on the air. Unless I get up to go to the bathroom, I guess, then -

question: What if--you're vomiting?
answer: What if I'm vomiting?

question: Do they show it?
answer: I guess -- I don't -- it's all in the contract. There's this million-page contract --

question: What happened? You described this "crazy-kooky" family who'd be a million laughs on TV?
answer: No! I barely even mentioned -it's just that, my friends, the people at work, whoever I'm regularly in contact with they want releases from.

question: They're gonna mock our foibles.
answer: Our what?

question: Look, my life is not so great, that I want it shown on television. And neither is yours.
answer: That's the point -- this could change things.

question: How?
answer: For instance... me and my friend Bucky are buying out my boss. His equipment, trucks, client list, the whole shmear.

question: What does that have to do with... ?
answer: If they keep Ed on for one full month, he gets a balloon payment. I borrow against that now, at the bank. Buy the business. And Ed becomes a silent partner. Now here's the beauty part. While we're on TV I plug the shit out of the business. Free advertising.

question: How about sex?
answer: I'11 have to pass, Al. And it's not an age thing --

question: No! Do they show you having sex?
answer: No. Kissing and hugging, okay, but if it's actual sex they have to cut away.

question: At what point?
answer: At the point -- I don't -- Look you'd be on TV maybe one or two times each. I'11 try to avoid I'11 go out of my way to avoid, getting together with you. Believe me.

question: At the point -- I don't -- Look you'd be on TV maybe one or two times each. I'11 try to avoid I'11 go out of my way to avoid, getting together with you. Believe me.
answer: Are you sure about this?

question: Hey, believe me -1 know I've got a great chance of making a fool of myself, here.
answer: Why do it?

question: I saw this show once. It was about logging. I was home sick, there was nothing else on. Do you know how they break up really bad log jams? You know, when they're really tangled... ?
answer: Cream rinse?

question: Dynamite.
answer: So?

question: So maybe this is my dynamite.
answer: Dynamite is dangerous.

question: Ed, can I see you a second.

question: Okay, so you understand? We're installing a permanent camera in your bedroom, one in the kitchen, one in the living room, plus, of course, there'll always be a couple of steady-cams following you.

question: I want you to take this. That has my work number, my home number, my pager number. I sleep three hours a night. Call me whenever you want to talk. Off the air, on the air, whenever. Okay?

question: Now look. Don't freeze up on me. I picked you because you had kind of a relaxed, go-with-the-flow quality. You're not going to lose that, are you?

question: I bet my career on you. You'd better be good.
answer: Don't say that. That's like... telling a guy before you have sex you'd better be good. You don't do that.

question: I do.
answer: Oh.

question: He's living with her!
answer: Ray, maybe this isn't ...

question: No, this is great. You'll love this. He's a singer.

question: No! Some drunk hit him over the head with his snifter -- you know, that thing they keep on the piano for tips -- and Marcia yanked a big hunk of glass out of his head. I mean my question is what was she doing in a bar in the first place?
answer: Ray --

question: She's an alcoholic, for Christ's sake.
answer: Oh, Jesus.

answer: What's the dif --

question: Richie! She spent six months dating a criminal
answer: She didn't know he was a criminal. They had a relationship. They --

question: "Quick pull off the highway" is not a relationship. Oh man, I gotta pee. What are you, hiding from the Police? Show your face, you look great. Doesn't she look great.
answer: Great.

question: While I'm gone, tell them about our cousin Lenny who's gay. We knew from when he was five.
answer: You do though, you look great.

question: Did you see that?

question: Her. That look. She likes the Ed guy better than she likes the brother.
answer: You're nuts.

question: This is Ray's apartment. Ray's got a big-screen TV and the Knicks are playing in L.A. tonight, so sometimes I come over after I work late and we watch the game here. He makes funny comments. He's really a good guy. He just...
answer: Who is it?

question: It's me, Ed.
answer: Hi.

question: You watching the ballgame?
answer: Uh, no, uh I'm a little tired. I fell asleep.

question: Oh. All right. I'11 watch at home, then.
answer: Yeah...

question: Who's --
answer: Oh shit... Hello... Shari, hi... Oh no! ... Oh God!

question: We'd better go...
answer: No, honey, it's not what it looks like-- Oh God ... Ed! That was Shari. She saw the whole thing on TV--

question: What is this? What's going on, who is that?
answer: It's the receptionist at one of the places I service video equipment -- she's very pretty and, you know, she never even talks to me and then today I come in and she's all "I saw you on TV the other night... You were so great ... " Next thing I know we're ...

question: Next thing you know! Why didn't you stop?
answer: Stop? I'm a guy. I don't stop. The woman's supposed to stop. We're the gas, they're the brakes.

question: Stop? I'm a guy. I don't stop. The woman's supposed to stop. We're the gas, they're the brakes.
answer: Ray, I finished the Snapple.

question: Fine!
answer: Is there more?

question: Why me?

question: You brought the girl!
answer: Please!

question: If I go over to Shari, the camera's going there, too.
answer: That's good. She'11 -- you know control herself. Look. If I go over there, she's just gonna slam the door on me. Just go over and beg her to talk to me, that's all. Please. You owe me for this!

question: Um... Shari knew you were coming over because she saw ...
answer: Right, yeah --

question: She really doesn't want you and the camera in here right now.
answer: No, I understand. That's - where is she, is she all right?

question: Shari, Ray feels --
answer: Don't defend that horse's ass to me.

question: I'm not. I'm not. I'm just Look -- you know, in a way, it's good. He got this out of his system now and he knows it's not worth it and, you know, someday if you guys got married or something --
answer: Ha!

question: Okay ...
answer: I've got news for you-- I never intended to marry him.

question: Oh... how come?
answer: Well, for one thing, he's a bad lay.

question: Oh my God.
answer: I mean bad.

question: Look, not having been there... I just think you're hurt and you're saying this to, you know, get back at him. I mean, I told Ray -- a couple of times -- that I thought you were one of the best and ... smartest and... most attractive women I've ever seen so...
answer: Really?

question: Oh my God. Oh my God.
answer: It's... okay

question: I kissed my boyfriend's brother on television!
answer: Well, when you put it that way.

question: Leave. Go.
answer: Can't we just --

question: Go!
answer: All right. Okay. I'11 ... see you.

question: What are we doing?
answer: I've got to tell you something. I have had a big thing for you for months.

question: Really?
answer: Yeah. I mean for months I've been seeing you with Ray you being his girlfriend and I kept wishing you were my girlfriend... But, you know, what could I do?

question: Me too. I mean I'm going out with Ray and I'm... thinking about you.
answer: Really?

question: Oh God, this is so weird.
answer: Weird? If this happened last month it would've been weird. Now with... the TV and... now it's just too weird. I'd better go. Once more? Hi, Al.

question: Weird? If this happened last month it would've been weird. Now with... the TV and... now it's just too weird. I'd better go. Once more? Hi, Al.
answer: Look. It's me.

question: Yeah. I brought you some movies.
answer: Anything good?

question: No, I intentionally picked out a lot of crap 'cause I don't like you. Is Mom here? I gotta talk to her.
answer: She's in the kitchen. I'd yell for her, but I'd die. You had a busy night last night.

question: Yeah. Ma...
answer: Eddie? ...

question: Yeah?
answer: Are the TV people with you?

answer: Send him away.

answer: No.

question: Do you want us to come in the kitchen?
answer: No. It's a mess.

question: Look, Ma, come on out. Really. I need to talk to you. This is my mother. Ma, do you know where Ray is? I've been calling him and I'm getting his machine and --
answer: Eddie, how could you do it? Your brother's girlfriend.

question: Hey, he cheated on her.
answer: He made a mistake.

question: I don't want to -- do you know where he is?
answer: No. Maybe he's watching. Tell him you're sorry. Tell him you'11 stay away from that girl.

question: I know you. This Shari is a passing fancy.
answer: No! I -- All right, look, if you hear from Ray.... tell him to call me, okay? How's Marcia? She all right?

question: I don't know. She's living with that "entertainer"...
answer: Well, who knows? Maybe she finally picked a winner this time.

question: Mm.
answer: You and Al lived together a few months before you got married -- after Dad left.

question: Oh my God!
answer: I mean, that worked out.

question: Oh my God!!
answer: I think we're through here.

question: Um, I'd like to get a new phone number, please... Because I'm getting calls from every nut case in America... Right, unlisted... Sure.
answer: Aren't you excited? He said he loved you on television!

question: He didn't say it. His stepfather said it.
answer: Well, the stepfather's cute... Seriously, how do you feel about Ed?

question: I'11 tell you something else. The old guy in the wheelchair? The stepfather? They're gonna have him die.
answer: What do you mean "they're gonna have him die?"

question: You know, for a tearjerker. The audience falls in love with this loveable old geezer in a wheelchair and then he dies, it's ... They know what they're doing.
answer: This is real, Bananahead!

question: So?
answer: So if it's a show and they have a guy die that's writing, but if it's real and they have a guy die that's murder.

question: Hi.
answer: ... Ray?

question: Yeah.
answer: Oh, man, I've been trying to call you.

question: I know.
answer: Look, we gotta talk.

question: Save it.
answer: Hey, you're that French guy on TV.

question: French guy?
answer: Monsieur Bad-a-lay.

question: Huh?
answer: Ed, why didn't you go over to see Shari today? That's what all our viewers were hoping you'd do.

question: Isn't she great? I mean, maybe just to me, but... I don't know, she's just --
answer: She's great, she's great. Why didn't you go see her?

question: No, I don't need to hear that. Cynthia?
answer: Yes, Ed.

question: Could we just talk alone for a second? I --
answer: Good idea. Could you all leave us alone for a few minutes? How you doing, Ed?

question: I feel like when I was a kid and my mother sent me to school in orange corduroy pants.
answer: Uh-huh?

question: And all the kids stared calling me "Pumpkin Ass." "Hey Pumpkin Ass," -- for like a year. So, now, I feel like everyone's watching me and, you know, I'm "Pumpkin Ass" again.
answer: Can I tell you something? I think you are fantastic. I think you have taken an idea and turned it into something explosive.

question: Yeah?
answer: Can I give you one bit of advice? About Shari?

question: Sure.
answer: A woman wants to be pursued.

question: This is so exciting! A real celebrity delivering my figs.

question: That Ray was a pig. Ed is doll. You latch on to him honey.
answer: By the X.

question: Some more make-up wouldn't do you any harm. On TV you look a little washed out.
answer: What would I actually have to do to get you to sign this?

question: Oh, an TV a minute and already an attitude.
answer: By the X. That's were two lines cross -- forming an X. What are you doing?

question: By the X. That's were two lines cross -- forming an X. What are you doing?
answer: I missed you. You know, I never saw you in your uniform before.

question: Yeah, well...
answer: It's really a tremendous turnoff.

question: You should see the one we wear when it rains.
answer: Sunday night at the Devils game, I'm driving the Zamboni.

question: The what?
answer: You know, the big machine that cleans the ice.

question: Oh yeah.
answer: It's quite an honor. Will you come with me? Look, I know this is weird. But... I don't want to wait. I really think we might have something together. Don't you? Come on. Be my zamboni date. They tore her dress! ...

question: It's quite an honor. Will you come with me? Look, I know this is weird. But... I don't want to wait. I really think we might have something together. Don't you? Come on. Be my zamboni date. They tore her dress! ...
answer: We're going to get you a bodyguard, don't worry. Ed, I have some news for you. We're picking up Ed TV for another month!

question: Yeah?!

question: Saturday, I think we should Compliments of Motorola. Hello... Marcia?? My sister. -- What? ... What, right now? ... I'm eating, I'm on a date! ... Well, where's your boyfriend -- what's his name? Cliff .... Then, call a cab... All right. Look, just don't start any trouble okay. Just sit there quietly 'til I get there... you're welcome. This used to be a regular thing. And the worst part, is while she'd be waiting for me to come down to some bar and get her, she'd start up with some guy and say "Wait 'til my brother gets here, he'11 kick your ass." So then I walk in and there's some rhinoceros in a windbreaker who tries to shove me into a shot glass. And Marcia's drunk and screaming "Kick his ass, Ed. Kick his ass." I think this is it. What was the tip-off? The enormous camera? Yeah. Keep up the good work. Oh great.
answer: Ed. What are you doing?

question: Hm? I'm, uh... Why isn't this drunken woman you? What's going on? Why did you want me to come down here?
answer: Cliff is here. He's performing. I wanted you to see him.

question: Oh! Oh -- okay, now I get it. It's "Star Search." You wanted me here because the camera comes with me.
answer: Ed, he needs a break. You don't know what kind of bad luck he's had --

question: I can imagine. You said you wanted nothing to do with this. You swore to me. "Don't come near me. Don't bring this into my life..."
answer: For God sakes, you said two words about some lousy pizza joint, the guy's a millionaire now. This could be my whole future we're talking about. Hi, I'm Ed's sister.

question: Um...
answer: What? I told you. If we... you know do it, they go away until ... we're done.

question: I know, but even if they go away, everybody in America knows what we're doing because... they went away.
answer: So? What do they think -- we're not kids --

question: I know, I ...
answer: Shari, I really like you...

question: I really like you too...
answer: ...if this ... ... weren't here... ?

question: ... yeah, then, but...
What?... Why?
answer: I can't take it anymore... I have no privacy. Even now! I'm crying and I can't stop and they won't go away. And now it's going to be another month!

question: Shari...
answer: Everybody hates me!

question: No. Who?
answer: Look at this. Page three of the Post.

question: Ohh...
answer: A poll. "Is Shari Good Enough for Ed?" Seventy-one per cent said "no." They hate me!

question: Who cares? I don't ca -- No. I do care. Shame on everybody. Shame on you! Well, just the seventy-one percent. The other...
answer: Twenty-nine.

question: Exactly. Boy, you're smart. Why are you so mean to her? What did she do to you? "Is she good enough for Ed?" Who the hell am I? Who the hell do you think I should be dating?

question: Really?

question: Wow... Yeah. God, I hope so. Hey, if it's free, it's me. You ready?

question: Hi.
answer: You don't recognize me.

question: No. Am I supposed to?
answer: It's me, Hank -- your father.

question: I told you the facts! He abandoned us -- those are the facts.
answer: So everything he told me yesterday was a lie. Everything. What do you mean practically? Did he really run away or did you throw him out like he says.

question: He ran away after I threw him out. How much is a new coil?
answer: So he was telling the truth you threw him out.

question: Yes.
answer: Yes to me or yes to the coil?

question: Both.
answer: Holy sh--

question: Whatever happened to Norman Rockwell?
answer: Who?

question: Norman Rockwell. He painted magazine covers. Folksy. A mailman, a boy scout, a kid visiting a doctor...
answer: Yeah, so... ?

question: They celebrated the common person.
answer: Well, I don't think you can get more common than me, Al.

question: All right -- do you want to know the truth? I took you and Marcia and Ray to my sister's on the train for the weekend and you all got chicken pox. So I took you home a day early and there was your father with a woman in our bed. Okay?
answer: Chicken pox? I was six. He didn't leave 'til I was twelve.

question: He... apologized, he begged me. He can be very... charming when it suits his purpose.
answer: But what was that whole story about him and a nurse?

question: She could've been a nurse.
answer: Could've been a nurse?

question: She had white shoes.
answer: So does Grandma. So does Shaquille O'Neal. You told me you had a hysterectomy and he ran off with your nurse.

question: What's the difference?
answer: The difference is for twenty years I thought one thing and now it's another thing.

question: He was no good. Do you remember how he used to scream at me? You used to cover your ears with dinner rolls. Also, no job was ever good enough for him. "Small potatoes, small potatoes." Al, you remember --
answer: Wait a minute. I thought you didn't know Al, 'til after Dad left. Oh my God. You and Al were - and that's why you threw him out.

answer: And what did he come back now for?

question: Who?
answer: Hank! All of a sudden. Because now you're famous and he can get something from you. I don't wan you to become a victim like Marcia. Not that you're a victim, honey. You're not. Life's just been a little hard on you, sweetie.

question: What do you think. I mean about... him. Should I just... have nothing to do with him? I mean...
answer: Have I ever said a bad word to you about your father?

question: No.
answer: Well, now I will. He was a crazy mean, son-of-a-bitch. But he was your father.

question: Hi... it's me, Ed. It's been two days, I want to see you... No, I won't let them follow me, I'11 sneak out... No it's not allowed, but I'm going for it... I'm on my way. Hi. They're not here.
answer: I tried to tell you over the phone -- my parents went to Atlantic City.

question: So?
answer: So my little brother's staying here. I'm sleeping with Rita.

question: Oh Je -- couldn't he sleep with Rita? We'11 all have a good time.
answer: I'm sorry.

question: Come on, let's go.
answer: Where?

question: Somewhere. Do you want to go to a motel?
answer: I feel like a criminal or, like we're cheating on someone.

question: Just... just relax. Okay? We won't do anything. We'11 just sit here for a while.
answer: Okay.

question: Come on... I need to talk.
answer: Are you all right?

question: She lied to me. I mean all my life, she's telling me one story and then... it turns out to be a completely different story. Come to me at some point -- tell me the truth. No. Not in my house. The truth is a stranger. And this is why Ray and Marcia are the way they are. Marcia gets involved with all these losers and sees no problem with herself - "How do they find me" she says. Ray cheats on you and then blames me for it. I'm the only one in the family who takes any responsibility for himself... Oh, man... Are you all right?
answer: Yeah... I saw that girl come on to you at the TV show.

question: Oh that was... no, I ... she just kind of trapped me into giving her a ride. It's you. I want you.
answer: ...yeah? Get them away from me.

question: It's not their fault.
answer: No. It's your fault.

question: What do you want me to do? You want me to quit the show?!
answer: No... Could you?

question: No. If I quit I don't get the balloon payment.
answer: The what?

question: Ray borrowed this whole tub of money against this balloon payment that I don't get if I qu -- it's too complicated. I -- Besides...
answer: What?

question: You see how people look at me. Like when they ask for my autograph or say "Hi" to me... It's like I'm a basketball player or a... you know, like I'm someone.
answer: Everybody's someone.

question: And so are you.
answer: I don't want to be famous for getting caught with my shirt off. If I'm going to be famous -- This is going right up your ass.

question: Come on.
answer: Look... maybe we just better put us on hold until this is over.

question: Now what? What's on the young man's agenda? We don't want to see him sitting around like a lovesick puppy.
answer: Young males do not want to see Ed get back with Shari.

question: Enough with her. That sailed.
answer: You know who the audience is requesting a lot? That girl, Jill, that Ed met at the Letterman show. She really scored.

question: Oh. Ed.
answer: Hi. Is Shari here?

question: No.
answer: What is she, at work?

question: She left.
answer: Well, when will she be back?

question: She won't.
answer: What are you talking about?

question: She left. She moved. She got Fed-Ex to give her a transfer and she left. She couldn't stand it anymore. We had people, news people, regular people, just sleeping in our hallway, going through our mail, our garbage. I mean it was she couldn't take it anymore. Now I've got to move. I can't afford this place by myself.
answer: I'm sorry. Where'd they send her?

question: She wouldn't tell me.
answer: Remember when you were interviewing me?

question: Remember when you were interviewing me?
answer: Yeah.

question: You asked me if I had a dream. I said "Sure, I have a dream. I just don't know what it is yet."
answer: Great line.

question: What if Shari's the dream?
answer: Ed, do you want my advice?

question: Yeah, that's why I called. I mean, maybe Fed-Ex would tell me where she moved --
answer: Leave her be.

question: You said a woman likes to be pursued.
answer: Pursued, not harassed. Give it some space. Can I tell you something -- as a friend? My sister was going with a guy they hit a little rough spot they started seeing other people they got back together and last month they had their third child For what it's worth.

question: You want to?
answer: Um... It's kind of ...

question: Are you busy tomorrow night?
answer: No.

question: Why don't you come over. And I'11 make dinner. And you bring a movie. And ... We'11 make a night of it ... okay?
answer: Sure. Oh man... Jesus! I'm starting to feel a little pressure.

question: Oh.
answer: Can I help with anything?

question: No. It's going to be about a half-hour.
answer: What is? Oh, dinner! Mm.

question: Good?
answer: Mm.

question: What?!
answer: Take him off the air.

question: What are you talking about? He's fine. He's out of the hospital already. The ratings are higher than ever.
answer: I'm telling you, it's peaked. Ed TV is an over-inflated balloon. Get it off before it explodes all over us.

question: With all due respect, Cynthia you're nuts. I'm giving him another month!
answer: Good luck.

question: Oh -- like this guy's ever been with a woman. How about I kick your ass 'til the crack goes the other way? All of a sudden, I'm like fair game for everyone. I'm like -- Oh my -- He wrote a book?! Ray wrote a book?! He never read a book!
answer: Who is it?

question: It's Ed.
answer: Ed! Come in - How've you been? They don't get cable here, so 1 can't watch you. Sit down. Quite a shithole, isn't it?

question: It could be, if you fixed it up. How did you... ? I mean how does anyone ... wind up like this?
answer: I was in jail.

question: The whole time? Eighteen years?
answer: No. Two times.

question: What...
answer: Check forging.

question: Oh, man! So...
answer: The last two years, I've been a limousine driver, but I don't see well anymore, so...

question: So you saw me on TV and you said "Hey, let me jump on this."
answer: I need help. How many times if just one little thing that I needed would've happened, it would've changed everything. If I had a few dollars when an opportunity came along or... the tumblers just never clicked for me.

question: All right... This is my father, I don't know what the hell he can do, but if anyone out there can help him -- get him a job - I'11 ... help you. I'11 ... mention your business or ... I don't know, we'11 figure it out. I gotta go.
answer: Ed... I'm sorry.

question: Yeah? That's good. Sorry is good. You know I finished that model.
answer: What...

question: The pirate ship. -- That we were doing "together." I finished it. It came out great! Because no one was standing over my shoulder bothering me - "That's too much glue. You're using too much glue."
answer: Do you still have it?

question: This Joma is so phoney! I mean, those things aren't really happening. I think they have writers making that stuff up for him. Hey, couldn't we do that? Hire some writers and have them write up some crazy situations I could get into?
answer: Ed, everything goes off. "Cheers" went off. "Mash" went off --

question: Yeah, but when they went off people weren't making fun of them. They weren't bozos! I'm Pumpkin Ass again!
answer: Ed --

question: You know, everything you asked me to do I did. I call you for advice about Shari you say - "Leave her be, see other people for a while." You just wanted me to get involved with Jill because it made for a better show.
answer: Ed --

question: No. You screwed up my life just so you could get higher ratings. You never gave a shit about me.
answer: Yeah? Well I'm not starting now.

question: Look, you put anybody on TV sixteen hours a day, at some point they're going to wind up rolling off a table on to a cat. I mean with no privacy, there's no... dignity.
answer: You know about that fireman who rescued that little girl?

question: When? Today?
answer: No! Like, ten years ago. In Texas. Baby... Jessica!

question: Oh right, right! She fell down, like a...
answer: Yeah, a thing. He became a big hero. He was on TV and there was a parade and a movie about him

question: Right, right...
answer: And then, uh... you know it blew over and he went back to being a fireman again.

question: Right.
answer: So he killed himself.

question: Oh.
answer: Hello.

question: Hello.
answer: Eddie...

question: Mom?
answer: I'm at the hospital.

question: What's the matter?!
answer: He's dead! Eddie, he's dead! It was his heart.

question: Oh God. What hospital?
answer: St. Joseph's.

question: Hi. I'm looking for my mother. Her name is --
answer: Mr. Pekurny.

question: Yes?
answer: I'm Dr. Geller. Your mother is just lying down for a few minutes. we gave her something to calm her down.

question: Thank you. Can I see her?
answer: Just wait here. She's coming right back out.

question: Mm... Oh, man... What about him -- did he suffer any or was it quick? I'd hate to think he...
answer: Very quick. Between you and me, it's not a bad way to go. Making love to your wife... it's very sweet.

question: Really? They were..
answer: According to your mother. When the paramedics got to the hotel, she told them that --

question: Hotel? What were they doing in a hotel?
answer: I ... don't know. I ...

question: How's your mother?
answer: Al!

question: Our neighbors gave me a ride.
answer: Al!!

question: Where is she? Is she all right?
answer: I thought -- I thought he was dead.

question: What happened?
answer: It was horrible. He called me up.

question: Who?
answer: Hank! He said he wanted to talk to me to apologize for everything he begged -- he cried. So I went to this horrible hotel he was staying in... I felt so sorry for him --

question: So you had sex with him?
answer: What?

question: The doctor said you were having sex.
answer: To you? In front of him? With the...

question: Yes. He assumed Hank was your husband. He didn't know.
answer: Oh my god! On TV!

question: Why? How...
answer: One thing led to another. He was my husband once.

question: But Al is your husband now!
answer: Do you think it's been easy for me? It's been years. Al can't have sex.

question: Well, he's the only one in America who doesn't! You're not going to talk to me? You're not even gonna say hello?
answer: I have nothing to say to you.

question: How are you doing? Is Cliff here?
answer: Cliff left her, thanks to you.

question: Me?!
answer: That's right. You put Cliff on television. So then he decided he was too good for her and he left.

question: I'11 take it.
answer: Right.

question: Are things gonna be okay with you and Mom? Is there anything I can --
answer: I'm moving out.

question: What?!
answer: I'm going to be living with my brother. He's not in such good shape as I am, but... I'm looking forward to the pillow fights.

question: Oh, Al ... This is just...
answer: Hank was always good with the ladies. Always good-looking. Hell, he's been dead for two days, he still looks better than me.

question: I want to tell you something... I love you. You're my father.
answer: I love you, too. I'11 build a pirate ship with you.

question: Hi, Ma.
answer: Ed! How did you know I was here?

question: You're famous. Somebody called me. What are you doing in a place like this?
answer: Why shouldn't I be in a place like this? I'm a whore!

question: Ma...
answer: I'm a tramp Meet your new father. The whole nation is laughing at us!

question: And how is this helping? come on say, good-night to all your new friends and let's go home.
answer: I'm a whore! Your bathrooms are filthy!

question: I'11 take her. You humiliated our mother on national television. You've single- handedly destroyed this family.
answer: I -- Oh, but that book you wrote was a real love-letter. That... toilet paper with covers. Oh great. Where's Moe?

question: Come on, Ma.
answer: Let's remember how I got into this. "Please, Eddie, do this for me. I can't get a break."

question: You know what your problem is?
answer: Yeah. My problem is I've got a brother who writes a sentence like "We grew up in a small, little bedroom." As opposed to a big, little bedroom?

question: I got paid by the word! No! Your problem is you don't ever want anything to be your fault.
answer: Me?! That's you!

question: I commit. I take a chance. You wanted to be the guy on TV, but you didn't want to say you wanted to. So you have me talk you into it so you get what you want, but if it goes bad it's not your fault.
answer: Moe! Yeah? So does a kick in the nuts.

question: In fact, we have a new concept. Since your family signed releases, we can follow them on camera even when you're not with them. We can cut around from family member to family member. Whoever's the most exciting at that moment.
answer: A couple of years ago my Uncle Roy got bit on the ass by a dog. So he gave me his tickets to the U.S. Open -- the tennis matches. So me and Ray, we tell our friends "Watch when Andre Agassi is gonna serve for the first time. When he's bouncing the ball and it's real quiet, we'11 yell "Whoop". And you'11 all hear us."

question: I see.
answer: You know what that is? It's sad. I mean it was just so we could be heard. So we could stand out from the crowd for a second. So we did it. But we had nothing to say. Just "Whoop". That's it. And the stupid part I mean the really stupid part is we thought it like... elevated us above the crowd. Where the fact is it made us stupider than the crowd.

question: I see.
answer: Stop saying "I see." You don't see. Cynthia, I owe you an apology.

question: Shut up.
answer: 1 bailed. I bailed on you.

question: Kinda'.
answer: It's what I do. I yell "Geronimo" and jump out of a relationship. You weren't able to make me feel safe or secure -- no easy job for any man, I admit -- and my problem is, if I think I'm losing, I pull myself out of the game. I bail. See? I told you, I'm the love coroner.

question: What did you do to your hair?
answer: My truck overheated, so I opened the hood and my hair got caught in the fan belt. So I had to get a haircut.
